summary.para: Represents formulas written in standard infix notation using standard precedence rules. The allowed symbols are non-negative numbers written using double-precision floating-point syntax; variables that consist of a letter or underscore followed by zero or more letters, underscores, or digits; parentheses; and the four operator symbols +, -, *, and /.

Associated with every formula are two delegates: a normalizer and a validator. The normalizer is used to convert variables into a canonical form, and the validator is used to add extra restrictions on the validity of a variable (beyond the standard requirement that it consist of a letter or underscore followed by zero or more letters, underscores, or digits.) Their use is described in detail in the constructor and method comments.

Creates a Formula from a string that consists of an infix expression written as described in the class comment. If the expression is syntactically invalid, throws a FormulaFormatException with an explanatory Message.
The associated normalizer is the identity function, and the associated validator maps every string to true.

Creates a Formula from a string that consists of an infix expression written as described in the class comment. If the expression is syntactically incorrect, throws a FormulaFormatException with an explanatory Message.
The associated normalizer and validator are the second and third parameters, respectively.

member.name: M:SpreadsheetUtilities.Formula.ExtraFollowing(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Checks that a token following a number, variable, or closed paren is an operator or closed paren.

member.name: M:SpreadsheetUtilities.Formula.ParenFollowing(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Checks that a token following an open paren or operator is followed by a number, variable, or opened paren.

member.name: M:SpreadsheetUtilities.Formula.isVariable(System.String)
member.summary: Checks that the given token is a possible variable according to Regular Expression parameters.

member.name: M:SpreadsheetUtilities.Formula.Evaluate(System.Func{System.String,System.Double})
member.summary: Evaluates this Formula, using the lookup delegate to determine the values of variables. When a variable symbol v needs to be determined, it should be looked up via lookup(normalize(v)). (Here, normalize is the normalizer that was passed to the constructor.)

member.name: M:SpreadsheetUtilities.Formula.operateOn(System.String,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Add or subtract the two numbers depending on the input operand.

member.name: M:SpreadsheetUtilities.Formula.GetVariables
member.summary: Enumerates the normalized versions of all of the variables that occur in this formula. No normalization may appear more than once in the enumeration, even if it appears more than once in this Formula.

member.name: M:SpreadsheetUtilities.Formula.ToString
member.summary: Returns a string containing no spaces which, if passed to the Formula constructor, will produce a Formula f such that this.Equals(f). All of the variables in the string should be normalized.

summary.para: If obj is null or obj is not a Formula, returns false. Otherwise, reports whether or not this Formula and obj are equal.

Two Formulae are considered equal if they consist of the same tokens in the same order. To determine token equality, all tokens are compared as strings except for numeric tokens, which are compared as doubles, and variable tokens, whose normalized forms are compared as strings.

member.name: M:SpreadsheetUtilities.Formula.op_Equality(SpreadsheetUtilities.Formula,SpreadsheetUtilities.Formula)
member.summary: Reports whether f1 == f2, using the notion of equality from the Equals method. Note that if both f1 and f2 are null, this method should return true. If one is null and one is not, this method should return false.

member.name: M:SpreadsheetUtilities.Formula.op_Inequality(SpreadsheetUtilities.Formula,SpreadsheetUtilities.Formula)
member.summary: Reports whether f1 != f2, using the notion of equality from the Equals method. Note that if both f1 and f2 are null, this method should return false. If one is null and one is not, this method should return true.

member.name: M:SpreadsheetUtilities.Formula.GetHashCode
member.summary: Returns a hash code for this Formula. If f1.Equals(f2), then it must be the case that f1.GetHashCode() == f2.GetHashCode(). Ideally, the probability that two randomly-generated unequal Formulae have the same hash code should be extremely small.

member.name: M:SpreadsheetUtilities.Formula.GetTokens(System.String)
member.summary: Given an expression, enumerates the tokens that compose it. Tokens are left paren; right paren; one of the four operator symbols; a string consisting of a letter or underscore followed by zero or more letters, digits, or underscores; a double literal; and anything that doesn't match one of those patterns. There are no empty tokens, and no token contains white space.

member.name: T:SpreadsheetUtilities.FormulaFormatException
member.summary: Used to report syntactic errors in the argument to the Formula constructor.

member.name: M:SpreadsheetUtilities.FormulaFormatException.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Constructs a FormulaFormatException containing the explanatory message.

member.name: T:SpreadsheetUtilities.FormulaError
member.summary: Used as a possible return value of the Formula.Evaluate method.

member.name: M:SpreadsheetUtilities.FormulaError.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Constructs a FormulaError containing the explanatory reason.

member.name: P:SpreadsheetUtilities.FormulaError.Reason
member.summary: The reason why this FormulaError was created.
